results.title: Body and soul [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Richard Curson Smith, ABC-TV (Australia), BBC and Oxford Film and Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australia: beyond the fatal shore [Widescreen]”.
Art critic Robert Hughes reflects on his relationship to Australia, 35 years after leaving the country. Contemplative after his near fatal car accident, Hughes reflects fondly on his childhood in Australia with an appreciation that only came from questioning his mortality. Episode one explores the concept of the pleasure seeking Aussie and whether there is more to us than our pursuit of leisure. Sydney’s annual Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras proves a focal point for the program which looks at beach culture, surf culture, the evolution of the wowser and the larrikin, censorship and homoeroticism in sport. Features interviews with Roy and H.G. (John Doyle and Greig Pickhaver), Dare Jennings and Bill Leeke. Includes footage of Norman Lindsay’s residence in the Blue Mountains, surf beaches on the East Coast, Old Sydney Town and an X-rated film shoot. Written and presented by Robert Hughes.

results.title: David Maybury-Lewis
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
David Maybury-Lewis’s series Millenium raised the awareness of the richness of tribal cultures around the world. In this “Face the Press” interview he expounds his theories on tribalism and how differently western societies perceive these cultures. Sometimes controversial in his approach, David Maybury-Lewis is an articulate original thinker. For those who have seen the Millenium series, the program will provide an insight into the mind of its creator; for those who haven’t, this program will generate an interest in his work.

results.title: Bridging the gap: the many worlds of Mandawuy
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Rhoda Roberts (Vox Populi), Sonia Voumard (The Age) and Mandawauy Yunupingu (teacher, musican, ambassador and father), on the eve of National Aborigines Day. Mandawuy explores the ways he is bridging the gap between black and white culture through both his band Yothu Yindi, the first aboriginal band to make the charts and to sign with an American record company; and as the Principal of the Yirrkala Community School in North East Arnhem Land, where, as the first aboriginal headmaster, he devised the curriculum mix of aboriginal and western studies known as “Both Ways Education”.

results.title: The Dalai Lama of Tibet
results.creator_credit: Austin Steele, John Walsh and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
The Dalai Lama answers questions at a press conference in Perth as part of his Australian tour. He discusses his philosophy of compassion in relation to conflict and political struggle, with particular reference to the Chinese invasion of Tibet. He also provides a brief outline of the events arising from the Chinese invasion. The Dalai Lama is the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people and an inspiration to thousands around the world. He has been living in exile since 1959.

results.title: Australia 2001:Thomas Keneally leads the push for a republi
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Paolo Totaro hosts a discussion between Thomas Keneally (Chairman of the Australian Republican Movement), David McNichol (The Bulletin) and D.D. McNichol (The Australian) on the issue of a Repblican Australia by the year 2001. They discuss the potential benefits to Australia becoming a republic, when this is likely to cccur, the politicalisation and composition of the Republican movement, possible candidates for Head of State and selection criteria, the Constitutional Commission 1988 and the liklihood of a hidden agenda within the Republican movement to undermine the current political system.

results.title: Sir David Attenborough
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Sir David Attenborough talks with three Australian journalists about his life’s work, what influences him, how he feels about his work, his thoughts on society and the environment, and his optimistic view of the future.

results.title: Three Prime Ministers
results.creator_credit: Kevin Ryder, John Walsh and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face the press”.
Three of the most significant politicians in recent Australian history are interviewed on their visions for Australia in the 21st Century. Gough Whitlam, Malcolm Fraser and Bob Hawke discuss what they see as the most important issues confronting Australia in the 1990’s, including the question of reconciliation between white and black Australians; the importance of trade and cultural links with Asia; the increasingly debilitating effects of permanent unemployment; and the possible consequences of republicanism on Australian identity and notions of statehood. The interviewers on this episode of “Face the Press” are Phillip Adams, Amanda Buckley and Paul Murphy.

results.title: The Dead next door
results.creator_credit: J.R. Bookwalter, Amsco Studios and Suburban Tempe
results.brief_description: J.R. Bookwalter’s The Dead Next Door is more than a passing homage to director George A. Romero’s ‘Living Dead’ trilogy. Shot on super-8 and partly financed by director Sam Raimi, this super low budget effort might be creaky at times but enthusiastically serves up the gore to considerable effect. The thin plot concerns a crack team of soldiers know as The Zombie squad who are called in to contain a virus that is bringing the dead back to life. Of course the zombies aren’t content with just being re-animated, as they chew their way through the human race leaving a messy trail behind them. Complicating the commandos squads mission further is an insane religious cult whose sole aim is to keep the zombies fed and alive in preparation for the final day of reckoning when the dead will finally replace the living. Cast includes Peter Ferry, Bogdan Pecic, Jolie Jackunas, Robert Kokai.

results.title: Swell Mamas
results.creator_credit: Matt Blackwood, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Lucy and Geraldine have been the best of friends since school, when they both became mums they decided that their love of surfing and of being in the water would not take a back seat, so they started ‘Swell Mamas’. Dozens of mums across Inverloch in south-eastern Victoria, get together every Friday morning to connect, to laugh, to share and to feel the water wash over them.
